context_meta.title: Klay Thompson's All-NBA Snub Is Bad News for Him, but Good News for Dubs
context_meta.summary: The "Splash Brother" finished well behind his backcourt mate, Stephen Curry, placing 26th in the overall voting (tied with Oklahoma City Thunder center Steven Adams and Utah Jazz rookie guard Donovan Mitchell, with all earning two third-place votes apiece). Curry earned an All-NBA Third Team slot. Beyond the loss of bragging rights, the snub has significant financial implications for Thompson, who won't qualify for a "supermax" contract extension. That's assuming the 28-year-old guard doesn't win NBA Most Valuable Player or Defensive Player of the Year before he hits free agency in 2019. context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Rockets are 1 win away from NBA Finals; Warriors get only 4 points from bench and 4th-quarter woes return
context_meta.summary: The Houston Rockets came away with a 98-94 win over the Golden State Warriors in Game 5 on Thursday night, to take a 3-2 lead in the Western Conference Finals. For a series between two juggernaut NBA teams, Warriors-Rockets has actually featured some very sloppy basketball. And, sure, much of this is surely do defense and the physical nature of high-intensity playoff games. But the first half of Game 5 was flat-out ugly, with both teams blowing numerous opportunities to open the game up, and the game went into halftime tied at 45-45. In the fourth quarter, the Warriors were outscored 27-22 and had several costly mistakes down the stretch. A few of those key Warriors' blunders came from Draymond

context_meta.title: Turnovers are punching a big hole in Warriors' hopes of beating the Rockets
context_meta.summary: It's a bad habit that surfaced all too often during the regular season. The Warriors' penchant for turning the ball over has reared its ugly head and because of it, they face elimination on Saturday.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: James on record 12th All-NBA 1st team; Harden also unanimous
context_meta.summary: NEW YORK – LeBron James was unanimously selected to the All-NBA first team for a record 12th time, while Houston's James Harden also appeared on all 100 first-team ballots. They were joined Thursday on the first team by New Orleans forward Anthony Davis, Golden State forward Kevin Durant and Portland guard Damian Lillard. James passed Kobe Bryant and Karl Malone with the 12th first-team selection of his 15-year career. He also was a second-team selection twice. The second team was forwards Giannis Antetokounmpo of Milwaukee and LaMarcus Aldridge of San Antonio, Philadelphia center Joel Embiid, and guards Russell Westbrook of Oklahoma City and DeMar DeRozan of Toronto. context_meta.title: Kristaps Porzingis finally breaks silence on David Fizdale's hiring
context_meta.summary: It doesn't seem Kristaps Porzingis is holding a Marc Gasol grudge. In breaking his silence since the Knicks hired David Fizdale, Porzingis on Thursday tweeted from Europe that he's finally spoken to the new coach — and had positive reviews. “Just had a great conversation on the phone with Coach Fiz. Man im excited!!!!! Lets gooo!!!” Porzingis tweeted. Of course, when Porzingis will be able to go is uncertain because of his rehab following surgery for an ACL tear, but his relationship with Fizdale will be vital and under the microscope. context_meta.title: Will Jayson Tatum Eventually Be Among Best Celtics Ever? Paul Pierce Thinks So
context_meta.summary: Greatness recognizes greatness, and Paul Pierce thinks Jayson Tatum is great. During the Boston Celtics' current postseason run, Tatum has been nothing short of stellar, and deservedly has drawn the attention of those everywhere. When the 20-year-old was selected by the Celtics out of Duke in the 2017 NBA Draft, he drew a few comparisons to Pierce. But in an interview with the Boston Herald, the Celtics legend indicated that Tatum is on his way to eventually becoming one of the best players in Celtics folklore. “I think he's going to be one of the great players in Celtic history,” Pierce told the Herald's Steve Bulpett. context_meta.title: Should Charlotte Hornets pursue a Hassan Whiteside trade? The short and long answer.
context_meta.summary: How center Hassan Whiteside was used in the playoffs suggests Miami Heat coach Erik Spoelstra isn't happy with how Whiteside is playing. A recent post by Whiteside on social media suggests Whiteside isn't happy with how he's being used. If Gastonia-native Whiteside and the Heat are headed for divorce, should the Charlotte Hornets pursue a trade? Short answer: No. Longer answer: Wouldn't that be adding tens of millions in payroll obligation for a younger version of what they already have? Whiteside is a former second-round pick (Sacramento Kings in 2010). He played overseas and in the G-League before catching on with the Heat in 2014. context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Anthony Davis Just Became Eligible For Largest Contract In NBA History
context_meta.summary: Anthony Davis already signed one record-setting deal. Might as well sign another? The New Orleans Pelicans superstar became eligible for a supermax contract Thursday by being named to an All-NBA Team for the second time in three seasons. The potential five-year deal, which he can sign next summer, projects to be worth $230 million, per ESPN front office insider Bobby Marks. That would make Davis' contract the largest in NBA history. Davis, the No. 1 overall pick in the 2012 NBA Draft, signed a five-year, $145 million contract extension in July 2015. context_meta.title: If LeBron James is tired... well he has damn good reason to be
context_meta.summary: After the Cavaliers' Eastern Conference Finals Game 5 loss to the Celtics on Wednesday, a reporter asked LeBron James if he was tired at this point of the postseason. “I had my moments,” James said. “I think everybody at this point is tired or worn down.” Cavaliers coach Tyronn Lue, meanwhile, admitted that he had snuck LeBron a little extra rest in both the second and fourth quarters, saying, “He looked a little tired to me.” Naturally, some of LeBron's ever-stubborn critics accused the four-time MVP of making excuses, of being weak-willed and of failing to live up to Michael Jordan, who apparently never got tired. context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Start Betting on Gambling Stocks
context_meta.summary: The Supreme Court recently ruled that individual states can choose whether to legalize or prohibit sports betting, voiding the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act of 1992 and paving the way for legalized gambling on all types of sports events outside of Las Vegas. In fact, Bank of America predicts that the gross revenue from legal sports betting will increase from the current $200 million annually to $5 billion-$10 billion in the next five years. Bank of America said it could see incremental annual sales opportunities between $250 million and $1 billion, but I think the upside is even bigger.

context_meta.title: It's Now Entirely Possible The Lakers End Up With Nothing This Summer
context_meta.summary: Just under zombie apocalypse rests a scenario that should have all of you cowering in fear: The L.A. Lakers will swing and miss at Paul George and LeBron James. “Whatever,” you say as you hold up a W sign with four outstretched fingers and roll back your eyes in a scoffing manner. Well, first off that's kind of rude and I'm not sure we can remain friends. Second, it's important to remember that the Lakers have sunk to desperate lows, becoming a pariah in the free agent market. It's only recently that they have become a savory option for marquee players blessed with sudden mobility in their contract status. context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: NBA Mock Draft 2018: Donte DiVincenzo looks like a first-round pick after strong combine performance
context_meta.summary: Donte DiVincenzo tested and measured well at the NBA Combine. And he played well too. So now most industry sources expect the Villanova star to remain in the 2018 NBA Draft considering he's a likely first-round pick widely viewed as an athletic guard who plays hard and aggressively, comes from a winning culture and shoots it well from 3-point range. Those are all good attributes. Assuming DiVincenzo doesn't return to school, it'll rob college basketball of yet another likely All-American while making an already deep draft even deeper. I have him going 20th to Minnesota in my updated mock draft.
